results.title: Admission impossible
results.creator_credit: Alec Morgan, Chris Oliver and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The very first Act passed by Australia’s first parliament was a law to exclude non-white races from Australia. “Admission impossible” is the true story of the behind-the-scenes political forces and propaganda that created the infamous White Australia Policy which was enforced until 1972. Eyewitness accounts and recently discovered confidential documents reveal how immigration officers carried out racial selectivity to discriminate against Asians, Jews and non-European applicants. The last part of the program discusses the impact the Vietnam War had on the reversal of this policy.

results.title: Action in Vietnam
results.creator_credit: John Abbott, Frank Bagnall and Department of the Army
results.brief_description: Scenes of the Australian Army First Battalion in South Vietnam. Shows part of a search and destroy mission in War Zone D. Also shows Vietnam under attack and the setting up of a medical post in a village. Narrated by Max Meldrum.

results.title: Across the frontiers
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson, Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This film was made at the invitation of the United Nations Organisation to illustrate the part played by Australia in a UNESCO campaign to foster better understanding between nations. Technical advances have broken down the old barriers to knowledge, but there still remain the barriers in men’s minds. The film illustrates the work being done by UNESCO in breaking down these remaining barriers.

results.title: About horses
results.creator_credit: Eric Thompson and Australian news and Information Bureau
results.brief_description: Machinery has replaced the horse in the field of light transport, and has invaded the medium and heavy traction and transport fields, but in the Australian outback there are jobs that only a horse can do. This film shows the types of horses bred in Australia from the heavy draught to the race-horse and the circus pony.

results.title: Aborigines of the Sea Coast
results.creator_credit: Charles P. Mountford, Australian National Film Board and Dept of Interior
results.brief_description: This film records the 1948 expedition to Arnhem Land sponsored by the National Geographical Society and the Smithsonian Institution. It shows the life of First Nations people of the sea coast at Yirrkala in the north-eastern corner of Arnhem Land. Demonstrates how, as children, they learn to handle canoes made from bark and as adults how they use them for fishing and hunting turtle. Shows how the canoes are made by stripping bark from a tree. The women of the tribe do the camp chores, collect firewood, make string bags, hunt goannas, and search for food plants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles P. Mountford, Australian National Film Board and Dept of Interior

results.title: Bush Mechanics: Episode 4: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Francis Jupurrula Kelly, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Australia and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description: The ‘Bush Mechanics’ comprise a group of five young Warlpiri men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, the ‘Bush Mechanics’ series follows the men across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits. In Episode 4, these involve covering thousands of kilometres across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.title: Free Climbing
results.brief_description:
Rock climbing is a recreation for some, an obsession for others. “Free Climbing” was filmed at Mt Arapiles and Mt Buffalo and features hair-raising shots as climbers demonstrate safety and technical skills.

Since this work was made (in 1986) there have been significant rediscoveries of indigenous cultural heritage around Mt Arapiles (2019 - 2022). Some of the climbing areas pictured may no longer be accessible due to measures to protect this heritage.

results.title: Fashions for Men
results.creator_credit: Mel F. Nichols, Winifred Lade, Department of Information, Frank Coffey and John Maynard
results.brief_description: Produced by the Department of Information, this government propaganda film shows the manufacture of uniforms in factories for the Australian armed forces serving in the Second World War. The film begins with an opening sequence that chronicles the development of Australia’s armed forces since colonisation in 1788, showing the styles of uniform worn over the decades by soldiers making “glorious history”. The film then explores the mass production and assembly lines of the various equipment required for contemporary uniforms including silk parachutes, khaki wool clothing, brass badges, tin and felt hats, and gas masks. The film is a fascinating insight into factory production of the period, and an example of propaganda encouraging patriotic values in support of Australia’s armed forces. As with many instructional films of the period, the film reflects now outdated gender stereotypes, showing women working in assembly lines sewing on buttons, while men work with steel machinery.

results.title: Flying menace
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the life cycle of the fruit fly, and the destruction it causes among Australian fruit. Illustrates the precautions being taken by the Department of Agriculture in checking the spread of the menace and shows how farmers should destroy contaminated fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
